paragraphs.text: Power without purpose: the tragic rule of David Cameron.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: When
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the history of David Cameron's time as prime minister is written
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: no doctrine will be named after him
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The government has been ideological, but not in a way that bears an intellectual imprint of the Conservative leader
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: There have been upheavals in schools, the health service and the benefits system
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: those revolutions belong to Michael Gove, Andrew Lansley and Iain Duncan Smith
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Cameron gave permission
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: he never pioneered
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Cameron has also said he abhors "isms" and wouldn't want posterity to anoint him with one
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Friends say this makes him a practical conservative of the old school
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: guided by ancient and uncodified British instincts of decency
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: His enemies think that is a posh way of saying he lacks principle
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: With no pattern of belief associated with his name, Cameron's legacy will be a collection of tactical manoeuvres, with as many prominent surrenders as victories
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The true spirit of "Cameronism" in education, for example, is better conveyed in the removal in 2014 of Gove to placate the teaching profession than in his appointment to shake up the department in the first place
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But in no field is the Tory leader's trademark better defined than in his approach to Europe
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: If any political manoeuvre deserves to be named after the Conservative leader
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: it is the habit of trying to sate the appetites of hardline Eurosceptics with morsels that would always leave them hungry
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It might be called the "Cameron concession"
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Thus has he fed the Eurosceptic pack enough to keep it snapping at his heels and frustrated it enough that his voice was drowned by angry barking
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Perhaps the saddest aspect of this spectacle is that it saw a potentially sound policy trampled in the melee
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The outline of Cameron's position is that Britain should stay in the EU but under changed terms
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: They will change anyway
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: because the priority for most other member states is bolstering the single currency
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: This involves the integration of a euro-core with serious implications for Britain's status one way or another
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: So the principle of pro- active renegotiation, ratified by referendum, is sound
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But Cameron spoiled a plausible position with cowardice
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: he set his renegotiation up as an empty vessel into which hardliners poured Ukip-ish fantasies of ending immigration
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: He bought the argument that says the terms on offer from Brussels get better the closer Britain gets to the exit
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: although that logic is commonly advanced by people who want the negotiations to fail
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The deadline for his referendum, the end of 2017, was plucked from thin air without regard for what was diplomatically feasible or economically wise
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But the chief reason Cameron's EU policy hasn't worked for him is that voters also consider motive when awarding merit
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Those who want a referendum in order to leave the EU mistrust the prime minister because he wants a different outcome
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: pro-Europeans don't trust Cameron to defend Britain's interests in Europe because the whole policy came about as a sop to the sceptics
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: That doesn't leave many people who think the Tories have the right policy for the right reason
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Europe exemplifies the problem
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it runs deeper
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Cameron's team are sure they are running on an admirable record: economic growth, rising employment, lower crime, a reduced deficit and reformed welfare
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: These are things, like the EU referendum, that should make the Tories popular
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: By the same calculation, Labour, lacking those credentials, should be out of the running
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Yet
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the campaign has started and Ed Miliband is still ahead
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Downing Street clings to the now familiar explanation that voters haven't properly engaged with the choice, and that the Tory surge will come at the eleventh hour when the reality of a possible Miliband regime penetrates the national consciousness
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: what if Cameron has hit the limit of credit available for five years in charge because even the good bits don't connect in people's minds with decent motives?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: That is what Labour strategists are banking on
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Miliband's personal ratings are bleak, except on measures of decency and empathy
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: So those are the leadership qualities his campaign aims to project
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The contrast they want to draw is between Cameron's ethical plasticity and a challenger who sticks to his beliefs
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Miliband will be cast as a man guided by what David Axelrod, Barack Obama's former aide now advising Labour, calls"a north star" - a compass point that tells voters a leader is propelled by something more noble than the salvation of his own skin
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Waverers who don't warm to Miliband(and who aren't irredeemably riddled with anti-Westminster rage) might still be persuaded that he is in politics for the right reason
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The opposite is true of Cameron
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Even those in his own party who like the direction of policy cannot sincerely claim that their leader is driven by much beyond a sense of entitlement to the job
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: That was less of an impediment in the past
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: For much of the 20th century, Britain was ruled by Conservatives who thought of political theory as something suspect or vulgar, a folly for continentals and socialists, and no substitute for the innate good sense drilled into English boys at the best schools
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The Thatcher revolution disrupted the patrician culture in the Conservative party, but not the underlying belief that Tory rule is a default setting for British politics; the norm to which the country tends
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: That assumption, more than economic growth, deficit reduction, an EU referendum or any other part of the prospectus, is what makes Cameron think he can stay on after May
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It is the confidence that he is an archetypal prime minister and the only credible candidate for the job
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Perhaps he will be proved right
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: He will have money and much of the press to amplify that view
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But even loyal Conservatives can't entirely ignore the intellectual void at the centre
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The right has decried it as often as the left
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The past five years have posed huge challenges for Britain regarding the economy, our place in Europe, England's relations with Scotland, the decline of trust in institutions
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: of which encounter with a great problem can it be said the prime minister truly rose to the occasion?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Cameron doesn't have big answers
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: he shrinks questions
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: that is how history will remember him, whatever happens in May
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: He successfully pursued power and spent it without purpose
paragraphs.label: assumption
